H0.text: Draining a springâ€‘fed pond would most likely cause a decrease in the number of woodpeckers in an ecosystem.

H1.text: Plowing and planting meadows is most likely to cause a decrease in the number of woodpeckers in an ecosystem.

H2.text: Destroying all dead trees and stumps would most likely cause a decrease in the number of woodpeckers in an ecosystem.

H3.text: Building a road around a small forest is the most likely cause of a decrease in the number of woodpeckers in an ecosystem.

A4.text: Being woodland birds, deforestation and clearance of land for agriculture and other purposes can reduce populations dramatically.

A5.text: The increase in the amount of deadwood is likely to be the major factor explaining the population increase of these species.

A6.text: Forest clearing to aid specific species of wildlife has been criticized because it can fragment forests leading to deleterious effects.

A7.text: Plantations can be an efficient source of wood but often come at the expense of natural forests and cultivate little habitat for biodiversity, such as dead and fallen trees or understory plants.
